questions.text: What is the basic unit of information in computing?
questions.explanation: Bit (binary digit) is the most basic unit of information in computing, representing 0 or 1.

questions.text: Which register holds the memory address of the next instruction?
questions.explanation: Program Counter (PC) holds the address of the next instruction to be executed.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the ALU?
questions.explanation: ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit) performs arithmetic and logical operations on data.

questions.text: Which memory type is fastest?
questions.explanation: Cache memory is the fastest but smallest memory, located close to CPU.

questions.text: What does CPU stand for?
questions.explanation: CPU stands for Central Processing Unit, the brain of the computer.

questions.text: Which addressing mode specifies the operand directly?
questions.explanation: Direct Addressing mode specifies the memory address of the operand directly.

questions.text: What is the purpose of pipelining?
questions.explanation: Pipelining increases CPU throughput by overlapping execution of multiple instructions.

questions.text: Which bus carries memory addresses?
questions.explanation: Address Bus carries memory addresses from CPU to memory.

questions.text: What is virtual memory?
options: Extension of physical memory using disk
questions.explanation: Virtual memory extends physical memory using disk storage, allowing larger programs to run.

questions.text: Which component performs I/O operations?
questions.explanation: I/O Processor (or I/O Controller) handles input/output operations.

questions.text: What is RISC architecture?
questions.explanation: RISC stands for Reduced Instruction Set Computer, with simple, fixed-length instructions.

questions.text: Which cache mapping technique is most flexible?
questions.explanation: Fully Associative Mapping is most flexible as any block can go anywhere in cache.

questions.text: What is the function of the control unit?
questions.explanation: Control Unit directs operation of processor, controlling flow of data.

questions.text: Which number system is base-16?
questions.explanation: Hexadecimal is base-16 number system using digits 0-9 and A-F.

questions.text: What is DMA?
questions.explanation: DMA (Direct Memory Access) allows devices to access memory without CPU intervention.
questions.hint: Think about memory access without CPU.

questions.text: Which flip-flop has two stable states?
questions.explanation: All these flip-flops have two stable states (0 and 1).

questions.text: What is the purpose of an interrupt?
questions.explanation: Interrupts signal CPU to handle urgent events, saving current state and executing interrupt handler.

questions.text: Which memory is non-volatile?
questions.explanation: ROM (Read-Only Memory) is non-volatile, retaining data without power.

questions.text: What is clock speed measured in?
questions.explanation: Clock speed is measured in Hertz (Hz), indicating cycles per second.

questions.text: Which addressing mode uses a register to hold address?
questions.explanation: Register Indirect Addressing uses a register to hold the memory address of the operand.

questions.text: What is a multiplexer?
questions.explanation: Multiplexer (MUX) selects one of several input signals and forwards it.

questions.text: Which RAID level provides mirroring?
questions.explanation: RAID 1 provides mirroring, duplicating data across drives.

questions.text: What is superscalar architecture?
questions.explanation: Superscalar architecture has multiple execution units to execute multiple instructions simultaneously.

questions.text: Which gate produces true only if all inputs are true?
questions.explanation: AND gate produces true (1) only if all inputs are true.

questions.text: What is the purpose of TLB?
questions.explanation: TLB (Translation Lookaside Buffer) caches page table entries for faster virtual-to-physical address translation.

questions.text: Which component performs floating-point operations?
questions.explanation: FPU (Floating-Point Unit) performs floating-point arithmetic operations.

questions.text: What is endianness?
questions.explanation: Endianness refers to byte ordering in memory (big-endian vs little-endian).

questions.text: Which memory uses capacitors to store data?
questions.explanation: DRAM (Dynamic RAM) uses capacitors to store data, requiring periodic refresh.

questions.text: What is CISC architecture?
questions.explanation: CISC stands for Complex Instruction Set Computer, with complex, variable-length instructions.

questions.text: Which component translates virtual to physical addresses?
questions.explanation: MMU (Memory Management Unit) translates virtual addresses to physical addresses.
